comments.commentBody:
.
OH, and as for the team nickname:

I asked on Facebook the night they won, but no one answered. I know I have heard "Lady Huskies", but that may have been in a less enlightened era.
There are already quite a few services that will prepare basic returns for free for low-income taxpayers.  Why have the government do this when it's already available?

I was astonished when I found out my relatives in Denmark don't file taxes; the government sends them a completed form, and my relatives can either adjust it or let it stand. After 30 seconds of shock, I thought, that's exactly the right way.

Even if you want government to act like a business, well, businesses don't expect you to figure out your own bill and pay it to them; they do the calculations and invoice you. In an electronic age, the government should do the calculations and the citizens should audit them, not the other way around.

By the way, TurboTax has become an absurd waste of money, getting bulkier, raising its price every year, and constantly advertising pricy add-ons (just like QuickBooks and Quicken do). I switched over to TaxAct years ago, which has all the same stuff but is streamlined, less in-your-face, and under $20/year.
Not exactly. The article says the $30 device works by amplifying the signal from your key fob (the $600 device in your example). So, without the fob, no entry.
I can't help but note the irony, that I can buy a device for $30 that will unlock my car, but if I want a new key that can do the same thing, Volvo will charge me $600 for it.

I would not be surprised if a refrigerator doesn't provide enough shielding, due to rubber door gaskets, the bottom or back or ice maker opening may not be all metal etc.

Even a microwave might not be good enough. Those are effectively faraday cages for cooking microwave frequencies, but not others. I've heard this trick for disabling my cell phone, tried it, and surprisingly my phone will still ring if I close it up inside the microwave. Here's one discussion: http://www.dailydot.com/news/edward-snowden-cell-phone-refrigerator-fara...

One of those metal coated mylar bags or a solid meal box suggested by others may work better. Try it by putting the car key inside and see if it will unlock your car.

Previously I thought it would be nice if I could unlock my car and the front door of my house with the same key, which would remain in my pocket while I had armfuls of bigger things to carry. Car companies could sell companion front-door locks, I thought. Maybe that wasn't such a great idea. Instead, maybe the front-door lock companies will start offering clunky non-digital locks that we can install in our cars.

VA hospitals are actually much more efficient than private hospitals (So bad example.) The problem with VA hospitals is Congress underfunds them on purpose in hopes do cause then to shut them down, so that private providers can get  a piece of the action, so the private industry will give contributions to congressmen. It's a dirty little circle of greed.

Try H&R Blocks Tax Cut. I switched years ago when Intuit was caught using the privileged personal tax return data for their own uses, expressly forbidden, That data is transmitted to them before then sent on to the IRS. Now this year they once again let their customers down. Once a company demonstrates it's true colors, I don't give them a second chance.

Tax Cut works great and is cheaper. You can find it around 50% off in early January every year.
The IRS already knows if they think you owe 10,000 so filing your own won't help

The US system is ridiculous.
I lived in Japan for 15 years. Taxes there were very painless.
My company's accounting department did most of the work, actually. Each winter, they would send out a questionnaire. I would provide them some information (such as the deductions I'm taking) and they would take care of the rest.

That was the entire process for most people.
If people had any additional income, they could file an adjustment early the following year. If you went to the tax office, they actually had people standing by to assist...for free.

The private sector's success in maintaining security around their client's information is horrendous.  Automation does not matter who it works for and the less that data is moved, the less opportunity for identity theft.  The information that already flows to the IRS is more than people realize.  Take the private-sector middleman out of the equation.

In Sweden you can even pay them with just a text message.

No paying TurboTax $25 per state e-filing (basically a criminal enterprise) or fighting with a copier or printer, the line at the post office, etc..,

I 100% agree with Mr. Bankman and have been thinking the same thing for years.  Why are we spending time typing figures from our W-2 form into Turbo-Tax?  It makes zero sense.  Similarly our stock sales should be automatically pre-entered (the IRS already receives info about the sale and could easily keep track of the basis if stock purchases were also reported to them).  Turbo-tax would still help us with the parts of our return which the IRS does not already know about -- entering in charitable donations, calculating expenses for rental property, etc.  But it could certainly cut down on the time spent, which I am all for!

.
DL -- 2 reasons for the wedding glut.

1. 6 years of improving economy, increased wages, reclamation of housing, new housing starts, and lowering health-care costs; plus, gently-rising consumer confidence and investment portfolios to fund receptions.

2. Mainly because, after the Supreme Court term ends, many more legal marriages will be able to take place. By getting married before then, people are avoiding the rush on wedding planners, florists, bakeries, etc. etc.

I'm frankly surprised we're not reading in the Comments of MORE weddings. Every day I expect JFC to announce he is re-marrying the Wife. (Guests will have to guess their table assignments based on avatars on the place cards.) And our Connecticut bartender seems like quite the catch.

Sheeesh. After the years-ago period when many of my contemporaries married, I thought I was pretty much done with weddings and buying gifts they'd probably never use. Then younger colleagues started getting married, and there we were again. Then, as states started adopting marriage equality, long-time couples started legalizing their status. This time I didn't buy the gifts but instead contributed to pro-equality organizations in states that where the struggle was continuing.

It seems there will always be something causing weddings. I can only be glad that I have escaped all these decades with my single-tude intact!

'Single-tude', DL? Au contraire, I'd say that you have all kinds of 'tude!

No regrets here either, but I hardly ever lock a door.
Martin, 3D I got with 2 letters and 9D I got with 1. Not that that means much. I thought maybe this was a themed puzzle until I remembered it was Friday. This guy has beady eyes, don't you think?
The article emphasizes several times that this is the top salary at a few top firms only.

THIS.  Add in that due to the grueling schedule most don't make it past 3 or 4 years in Biglaw.  By that time, even paying 3k per month in loans, the fool still has several years left to pay back the huge loan debt.

It's important to "unpack" the $160,000 starting salary.

First, only perhaps 10% of students at most schools will ever be offered one of these jobs (higher at some elite schools). That's why the starting salary has not increased - the big firms hold all of the cards in terms of supply and demand and basically dictate terms to the new associates. (For the remaining 90% of law graduates ignored by this article, a majority of them can expect unemployment upon graduation or a job with a starting salary of around $40,000, with no wage and hour protections in most states).

Second, importantly, is that this is an 80 hour a week job, if not more. Just doing some rough math, these associates are earning perhaps $40 dollars per hour. That's nothing to sniff at, certainly, but less and less relative to the $15 dollar per hour minimum wage which could be here 4 years down the road in some areas. It's perhaps on par with a machinist at Boeing, though of course, working just 40 hours per week.

Third, not ignored in this article, are the debt considerations involved in pursuing the degree in the first place. Someone making $160,000 is going to be on an aggressive repayment track, which will eat into discretionary income significantly, particularly in a high-priced urban area.

In summary, Big Firm Attorney is not a glamorous job, and the salary is not particularly impressive given what you are expected to give up to do the job.

That really sucks. One of my dad's best friends once we moved to L.A. was Charley Lloyd, law partner of Tom Bradley. Back then I'd wanted to be a lawyer, and my dad introduced me (at 15) to Charley and I got to tour his office and ask him about what it took to be a lawyer. He said if I made it through law school I could come back and work in his office.

So what do I do? I stick with computers. Long story short? Most I ever made was $85K, now I make nothing and am treated as if I am Methuselah by most in the industry and to make matters worse, am being told about how many jobs I haven't gotten because I didn't already have a job. If I'd gone the attorney way I'd be a millionaire right now.

If you are making $160k a year, remember this their first year salary, the debt is serviceable. Depending on the approach to paying off debt a new lawyer making that salary could wipe out the loans within 5 years.

I work in manufacturing, but I would somewhat sympathetically point out that "the biggest legal markets" are also the most expensive.  Add student debt and, no, I don't envy those first years lucky enough to get the better spots.  I pity the less fortunate.

Any trial lawyer worth his or her salt knows that the judge presiding in a given case is as much an adversary as the attorney at the other trial table. The judge calls the balls and strikes and there is bound to be contention with an alert aggressive litigator whose job it is to protect his client as well as the record. Of course this is to be accomplished with decorum, without rudeness and respect for the judge's office. Based on the Times' coverage it appears that Bharara has not acted out of line but instead moves boldly given the volume and importance of the cases he prosecutes. Sounds like to me that the New York bench ought to listen, make rulings and let cases unfold naturally.
The good old USA and our fake system of democracy, justice, and equality.
So Federal judges and Federal prosecutors party together?
Hypocrisy, or self-preservation?
Oh my, the same people who want 1% to share wealth their with them are crying wolf when asked to share some wealth with world's poor. What a hypocrisy!

Government doesn't represent the people. Corporation rule. Our elections are a farce. My favorite American this week is the guy who flew his little plane on the Capital lawn unimpeded, having announced in advance to the Tampa Times and know to the Stooges Secret Service for over a year. Our country is in a persistent vegetative state,

Have heard negative things about this whole endeavor, and one is also in the works with the EU countries as well, that it will be even worse for the regular American than NAFTA was.  Also that we won't know the provisions till three years after it is in place.  I understand Elizabeth Warren asked why it had to be so secretive, and was told that it would not be passed it the public knew about the provisions.  That goes to show that treating these negotiations as secret is no doubt not in the interests of the general public, which these government officials are supposed to representing.  How will our interests be protected?
I'm a liberal and I know it's doing its job right now siphoning wealth out of the lower and middle classes and into the upper one percent, as it's designed to.

Beijing is watching with amusement, as the strategies unfold.

If the BRICS Bank and the AIIB demonstrate China’s policy, it is a policy that offers shared prosperity, and capital investment into infrastructure of poorer nations, so these recipients of Chinese largess can grow richer and buy more stuff Made in China, not to mention that Chinese exporters are also expected to benefit from the supported infrastructure projects. Sounds rational.

In contrast, the TPP is not about merchandise trade at all. It leverages the military muscle of America to disrobe all the member countries of the last line of defense against financial predation. Hidden in the fine print of the TPP is the requirement of removal of sovereign control over capital accounts, and of mandatory “financial reforms” – translated: unfettered access for bloodsucking American “banks” to do DERIVATIVES. What better victims than the banks of weak nations whose existence is dependent on the pleasure of the U.S. military? Just like opium, this is sold under the guise of “free trade”. For the derivatives casino to grow from the present US$1.3 Quadrillion to double and re-double, more new defenseless victims are needed.

Also, the TPP has this beautiful mechanism for arbitration of disputes OUTSIDE the sovereign courts of the member nations.
Only a handful of our representatives in Congress who are pushing this far-reaching deal actually know what's in it.

Almost all of the press and the media is owned by six corporations. Those media entities pay more to lobby than any other industry. They have worked to shape consensus reality for forty years now to reach this moment of corruption.
Press is part of coverup.

This is an abomination. Where is the press and the media coverage of this sell out bill? This should be front and center in the newspapers and on the evening news every day. Only a handful of our representatives in Congress have a conscience. The rest are building up equity in their current jobs and then on to their cushy jobs in banking, financial institutions or the defense contractors.

Pretty skeptical on how this will make the playing field fair for American workers, unless the caveat is that fair means being unable to compete with cheaper labor.

What's more of a concern is who's going to be eating the most out of the pie.
